Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration."},{"name":"preload","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process."},{"name":"purge","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, purges this cache store when it starts up."},{"name":"shared","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store."},{"name":"singleton","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. Treated as an absolute path, unless the 'relative-to' attribute is specified, in which case the value is treated as relative to that path. <p>If treated as an absolute path, the actual runtime pathname specified by the value of this attribute will be determined as follows: <\/p>If this value is already absolute, then the value is directly used.  Otherwise the runtime pathname is resolved in a system-dependent way.  On UNIX systems, a relative pathname is made absolute by resolving it against the current user directory. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled."},{"name":"passivation","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration."},{"name":"preload","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process."},{"name":"purge","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, purges this cache store when it starts up."},{"name":"shared","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store."},{"name":"singleton","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled."},{"name":"passivation","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration."},{"name":"preload","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process."},{"name":"purge","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, purges this cache store when it starts up."},{"name":"shared","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store."},{"name":"singleton","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled."},{"name":"passivation","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration."},{"name":"preload","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process."},{"name":"purge","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, purges this cache store when it starts up."},{"name":"shared","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store."},{"name":"singleton","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. SingletonStore is a delegating cache store used for situations when only one instance in a cluster should interact with the underlying store."},{"name":"properties","type":"javax.management.openmbean.TabularData","desc":"A list of cache store properties."},{"name":"binaryKeyedTable","type":"javax.management.openmbean.CompositeData","desc":"Defines a table used to store cache entries whose keys cannot be expressed as strings."},{"name":"stringKeyedTable","type":"javax.management.openmbean.CompositeData","desc":"Defines a table used to store persistent cache entries."},{"name":"datasource","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"The jndi name of the data source used to connect to this store."}],"ret":"java.lang.Void","desc":"Adds a JDBC cache store configuration element to the cache."},"addStoreStringJdbc":{"args":[{"name":"dataSource","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"References the data source used to connect to this store."},{"name":"dialect","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"The dialect of this datastore."},{"name":"fetchState","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, fetch persistent state when joining a cluster. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled."},{"name":"passivation","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration."},{"name":"preload","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process."},{"name":"purge","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, purges this cache store when it starts up."},{"name":"shared","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store."},{"name":"singleton","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. A value of 'none', the default, indicates that the explicit value of max-pool-size should be used. A value of 'from-worker-pools' indicates that the max pool size should be derived from the size of the total threads for all worker pools configured on the system. A value of 'from-cpu-count' indicates that the max pool size should be derived from the total number of processors available on the system. Note that the computation isn't a 1:1 mapping, the values may or may not be augmented by other factors."},{"name":"maxPoolSize","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"The maximum number of bean instances that the pool can hold at a given point in time"},{"name":"timeout","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"The maximum amount of time to wait for a bean instance to be available from the pool"},{"name":"timeoutUnit","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"The instance acquisition timeout unit"}],"ret":"java.lang.Void","desc":"Adds a bean instance pool which has a strict upper limit for bean instances"}},"attr":{"inVmRemoteInterfaceInvocationPassByValue":{"rw":true,"type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If set to false, the parameters to invocations on remote interface of an EJB, will be passed by reference. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process."},{"name":"purge","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, purges this cache store when it starts up."},{"name":"shared","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store."},{"name":"singleton","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process."},{"name":"purge","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, purges this cache store when it starts up."},{"name":"shared","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store."},{"name":"singleton","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. SingletonStore is a delegating cache store used for situations when only one instance in a cluster should interact with the underlying store."},{"name":"properties","type":"javax.management.openmbean.TabularData","desc":"A list of cache store properties."}],"ret":"java.lang.Void","desc":"Adds a file cache store configuration element to the cache."},"addStoreNone":{"args":[],"ret":"java.lang.Void","desc":"Adds a store-less configuration to this cache"},"addStoreRemote":{"args":[{"name":"cache","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"The name of the remote cache to use for this remote store."},{"name":"socketTimeout","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"A socket timeout for remote cache communication."},{"name":"tcpNoDelay","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"A TCP_NODELAY value for remote cache communication."},{"name":"remoteServers","type":"[Ljava.lang.String;","desc":"A list of remote servers for this cache store."},{"name":"fetchState","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"If true, fetch persistent state when joining a cluster. Such a thread pool has a core and maximum size and a specified queue length.  When a task is submitted, if the number of running threads is less than the core size, a new thread is created. Each mapping should be evaluated in declared order, with the first successful match used to determine the destination."},"port":{"rw":true,"type":"java.lang.Integer","desc":"Number of the port to which the socket should be bound."},"bound":{"rw":false,"type":"java.lang.Boolean","desc":"Whether an actual socket using this socket binding configuration has been bound."},"multicastAddress":{"rw":true,"type":"java.lang.String","desc":"Multicast address on which the socket should receive multicast traffic. The IPv6 wildcard address (::) will be used unless the java.net.preferIpV4Stack system property is set to true, in which case the IPv4 wildcard address (0.0.0.0) will be used. If a socket is bound to an IPv6 anylocal address on a dual-stack machine, it can accept both IPv6 and IPv4 traffic; if it is bound to an IPv4 (IPv4-mapped) anylocal address, it can only accept IPv4 traffic."},{"name":"inetAddress","type":"java.lang.String","desc":"Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not the address matches the given value. A 'loopback address' may not actually be configured on the machine's loopback interface. Differs from inet-address in that the given value will be used even if no NIC can be found that has the IP specified address associated with it. An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection."},{"name":"multicast","type":"java.lang.Boolean","desc":"Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not its network interface supports multicast. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled."},{"name":"passivation","type":"java.lang.Boolean","desc":"If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration."},{"name":"preload","type":"java.lang.Boolean","desc":"If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process."},{"name":"purge","type":"java.lang.Boolean","desc":"If true, purges this cache store when it starts up."},{"name":"shared","type":"java.lang.Boolean","desc":"This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store."},{"name":"singleton","type":"java.lang.Boolean","desc":"If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled.
